title: Inside a cartoonist’s world - Liza Donnelly

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the enduring popularity of cartoons as an art form?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a complex medium that requires a lot of interpretation.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a universal medium that can be enjoyed and understood by people around the world.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a relatively new form of art that has only gained popularity in recent years.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a static medium that does not allow for much creativity.

multiple-choice.question: Where do cartoonists often get their ideas from?

options.label: A
options.text: Only from reading newspapers and watching television.

options.label: B
options.text: Only from observing life and talking to people.

options.label: C
options.text: A variety of places, including observing life, reading, and online sources.

options.label: D
options.text: Only from their own personal experiences.

options.text: They are only responsible for drawing the images.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only responsible for writing the dialogue.

options.label: C
options.text: They are like a playwright, director, stage designer, choreographer, and costume designer all rolled into one.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only responsible for coming up with the idea.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "dance" between the image and words in a cartoon?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a confusing and disjointed message.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a beautiful and aesthetically pleasing image.

options.label: C
options.text: To make sense and advance the idea or punchline.

options.label: D
options.text: To add unnecessary details to the cartoon.

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical process for executing a cartoon?

options.label: A
options.text: Sketching the idea with pencil, then inking it with pen using a light box.

options.label: B
options.text: Visualizing the image in their head and drawing directly on the paper in pen.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of different techniques, including pencil, pen, and digital tools.

options.label: D
options.text: Only using digital tools, such as Photoshop.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding gray tone, or a wash, to a cartoon?

options.label: A
options.text: To add color to the image.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a more detailed and realistic image.

options.label: C
options.text: To add depth and dimension to the image.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the image more confusing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of new technologies, such as Photoshop, in creating cartoons?

options.label: A
options.text: They have replaced traditional drawing techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only used for adding color to the image.

title: Pizza physics (New York-style) - Colm Kelleher

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why folding a pizza slice at the crust helps prevent the tip from falling over?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the folded shape is more symmetrical

options.label: D
options.text: Because the folded shape is less affected by gravity

options.label: A
options.text: They are easy to stretch but hard to bend

options.text: They are easy to bend but hard to stretch

options.label: C
options.text: They are equally easy to bend and stretch

options.label: D
options.text: They are equally hard to bend and stretch

options.label: B
options.text: Because the sphere has a smaller surface area

options.label: C
options.text: Because the sphere has a different curvature

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sphere has a different shape

multiple-choice.question: Why does the pizza slice require more force to bend when it is folded at the crust?

options.text: Because the folded shape has a larger surface area

options.label: B
options.text: Because the folded shape has a smaller surface area

options.label: C
options.text: Because the folded shape requires stretching

options.label: D
options.text: Because the folded shape requires bending

options.label: A
options.text: That gravity is strong enough to bend the tip of the pizza

options.label: B
options.text: That gravity is not strong enough to bend the tip of the pizza

options.label: C
options.text: That the shape of the pizza is irrelevant to its bending

options.label: D
options.text: That the size of the pizza is irrelevant to its bending

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader lesson that can be learned from the example of folding a pizza slice?

options.label: A
options.text: That math is only relevant to abstract concepts

options.label: B
options.text: That math is only relevant to real-world applications

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How do cancer cells behave differently from healthy ones? - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which a single cell divides and grows into 100 trillion cells called?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The cell continues to divide normally

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a cell's incorrect instructions being passed along to its offspring?

options.label: C
options.text: The cell continues to divide recklessly

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of radiation and most forms of chemotherapy in cancer treatment?

options.label: B
options.text: To physically shred the cells' DNA or disrupt the copying machinery

options.label: A

options.text: Because they are not specific to cancer cells

options.text: Because they only target healthy cells

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because the treatments only target cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: Because the treatments affect frequently dividing cells

options.label: D
options.text: Because the treatments are too aggressive

multiple-choice.question: What is the main strength of cancer cells that is turned into a weakness by chemotherapeutic drugs?

options.text: Their ability to divide rapidly and recklessly

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to evade the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of cancer treatment in relation to cell growth?

options.label: C
options.text: To turn cancer's rapid growth into a weakness

title: Let's talk about sex - John Bohannon and Black Label Movement

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of high school seniors in the 1980s had tried marijuana?

options.label: C

options.text: To outsource the conversation to experts and media

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is more efficient than cloning

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is necessary for the development of complex life forms

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a result of random mutation

options.label: B

options.text: He believes that these approaches are a waste of time and resources

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that these approaches are morally wrong

options.label: D
options.text: He was already knowledgeable and experienced

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's point about the importance of honesty and self-reflection in communicating with children about sensitive topics?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That it is only necessary to be honest about the facts

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that this idea is accurate and should be protected

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that this idea is a myth and that children are naturally curious and exploratory

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that this idea is outdated and no longer relevant

options.text: He believes that this idea is only true for certain children

options.label: A
options.text: That sex is something to be ashamed of

options.label: B
options.text: That sex is something to be feared

options.label: C
options.text: That sex is a natural and beautiful part of life

options.label: D

title: How did English evolve? - Kate Gardoqui

multiple-choice.question: What was one benefit for the Celts in Britain when they were ruled by the Romans?

options.label: A
options.text: The Romans introduced their language to the Celts.

options.label: B
options.text: The Romans protected them from the barbarian Saxon tribes of Northern Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: The Romans forced the Celts to adopt their customs.

options.label: D
options.text: The Romans made the Celts their allies in war.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following Germanic tribes did NOT invade Britain after the Roman Empire crumbled?

What event in the 700's affected the language spoken in Britain?

options.label: B
options.text: A series of Viking invasions began.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Isles were unified under one ruler.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Norman conquest of 1066 affect the language spoken in Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the complete replacement of Old English with French.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced Latin words into the English language.

options.label: C
options.text: It created a two-tiered society with French-speaking aristocracy and Old English-speaking peasants.

multiple-choice.question: What is the connotation associated with words of French origin in the English language?
Analyze the difference in connotation between the phrases "hearty welcome" and "cordial reception." What can be inferred about the origins of the words in these phrases?

options.label: A
options.text: "Hearty welcome" has a more formal tone, indicating that its words come from French.

options.label: B
options.text: "Cordial reception" has a more informal tone, indicating that its words come from Old English.

options.label: C
options.text: "Hearty welcome" has a more casual tone, indicating that its words come from Old English, while "cordial reception" has a more formal tone, indicating that its words come from French.

options.label: D
options.text: The phrases have the same connotation, indicating that their words come from the same origin.

multiple-choice.question: Apply your knowledge of the history of the English language to explain why using words from French or Latin might make a speaker sound more sophisticated.

options.label: A
options.text: Because French and Latin words are more difficult to pronounce.

options.label: B
options.text: Because French and Latin words are associated with nobility and authority.

options.label: C
options.text: Because French and Latin words are more commonly used in everyday conversation.

options.label: D
options.text: Because French and Latin words are more descriptive and vivid.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the relationship between language and history based on the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: Language reflects the cultural and social context of its time.

options.label: C
options.text: Language is only influenced by major historical events.

options.label: D
options.text: Language is a static entity that does not change over time.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptualize the idea that "our history lives in the words we speak and hear." What does this mean in the context of the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: That the English language is a direct result of historical events.

options.label: B
options.text: That the English language has been influenced by various cultures and societies throughout history.

options.label: C
options.text: That the English language is a reflection of the present moment only.

options.label: D
options.text: That the English language has no connection to history.
